ranked_diseases.explanation: KBG syndrome is characterized by macrodontia (particularly of upper central incisors), short stature, skeletal anomalies including delayed bone age, and hand abnormalities. This matches all four presented phenotypes.
Features short stature, delayed bone age, and skeletal abnormalities of hands. While macrodontia is not typical, dental anomalies can occur.
Presents with short stature, skeletal anomalies including hand abnormalities, and delayed bone maturation. Dental anomalies are common but macrodontia is less typical.
X-linked form of Kabuki syndrome with similar features to type 1, including short stature and skeletal anomalies, though macrodontia is not a primary feature.
Features short stature, characteristic hand abnormalities (broad thumbs), and delayed bone age. Dental anomalies occur but macrodontia is uncommon.
Presents with short stature, hand abnormalities (oligodactyly, syndactyly), and delayed bone maturation. Dental anomalies can occur but macrodontia is not typical.
Features short stature, hand abnormalities (hypoplastic fifth digits), and delayed bone age. Dental anomalies are possible but macrodontia is rare.
Can present with short stature, hand anomalies, and skeletal delays. Dental abnormalities occur but macrodontia is not a primary feature.
